channel.title: Tom Ruddell's design and technology blog
channel.description: I'm an engineer working in Glasgow, Scotland. This personal blog is a collection of my writing on whatever I find interesting, mainly on the themes of design and sustainability.

item.title: How would we plan technology?
item.description: I fly through two contrasting planning initiatives in UK aerospace history in search of tangible examples of technology development being chosen by logic, without market pressures in the cockpit.

item.title: Welcome to hell; please drive safely
item.description: This post features some history and future of UK pedestrian crossings, excerpts from British Standard BS 8442, ramshackle hand-cut copper circuits and Belisha Beacon halloween costumes. Welcome to hell; please drive safely.

item.title: On Dyson, techno-centric design and social consumption
item.description: Dyson exemplifies a particularly ‘techno-centric’ design approach and in this post I wanted to explore how that manifests in their product design and marketing strategy, as well as what broader impact it has on designers and the field of design itself.

item.title: Early modern grain elevators: “listen to the counsels of the American engineers”
item.description: Join me as I learn about grain elevators, explore their design evolution and try to understand why they were such powerful metaphors for the leading European Modern architects.

item.title: Lanark to Sloy – a look at early Scottish Hydro
item.description: With help from some amazing archival images, this post takes a trip from Lanark to Sloy and explores the significance of these pioneering 1926 stations, a year before their centennary!

item.title: Celtic Code: Drawing knots with Python
item.description: What would have happened if the Celts had access to computers and specifically the Python programming language? This post answers that question with a fun web-app that lets you create and save your own Celtic knots in-browser, as well as briefly exploring the history of the Celts, knots and rope.

item.title: Santa's Sustainability Audit: Scope 1, 2 and 3
item.description: Ever wondered what would happen if Santa did a life cycle assessment?

item.title: A week at the International Electrotechnical Commission
item.description: I recently attended the annual International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC) General Meeting as a Young Professional. After a packed week of networking, workshops and talks I’ve come away with a hard-to-get insight into how the IEC works, how to get involved and what a career in international standards is like. I also know about five million new acronyms.

item.title: The world's oldest working mechanical clock
item.description: I have made a 3D model of the world’s oldest working mechanical clock, in Salisbury Cathedral. This post explores timekeeping technology through the times, the clock itself and reflects on design-for-longevity.

item.title: Migration and modernism: Nikolaus Pevsner
item.description: In 1933 the 31 year-old Nikolaus Pevsner, an art and architectural historian lecturing at University of Gottingen in Germany, was forced from his post and emigrated to the UK, settling in Hampstead where he would live the rest of his life.

item.title: Lighting and Sustainability: Engineering Change
item.description: Article on remanufacturing luminaires for Lighting Journal (May 2023)

item.title: GreenLight Alliance: Code of Practice for luminaire remanufacture
item.description: Article building the case for a code of practice for the remanufacture of luminaires, for arc magazine issue 130.

item.title: GreenLight Alliance: A Dive into Remanufacturing
item.description: Article introducing remanufacturing in the lighting industry, for arc magazine issue 126.

item.title: Entering a new geopolitical era: The transition to renewables and its geopolitical implications
item.description: Exploring global energy production and demand trends and exploring possible geopolitical outcomes.

item.title: Heat Networks: Basics
item.description: Exploring heat networks, heat networks and the practicalities.

item.title: Lithium
item.description: Looking at the growing importance of Lithium as a key material used in the production of batteries for energy storage and EVs, and the state of the supplychain - in particular the political turmoil in Bolivia, a major exporter.

item.title: An Open Letter to the Planet
item.description: Produced as part of my "Think Slow Act Fast" project, I wrote and personally printed and bound this into a pamphlet and handed it out at various events, including the 2019 Climate Strikes (20th - 27th September 2019).

item.title: Concerns regarding the Global Trade in Clothing
item.description: A short essay on the human and environmental costs associated with the textile industry under capitalism.

item.title: Intuitive Design: Shower Thoughts
item.description: Reflecting on usability in product design, focusing on the example of bathroom showers.
